dialogs.text: Found in 2005, the records of the old National Police Archive of Guatemala contained important documents related to police history, including during the periods of civil war and dictatorships. The archival materials included evidence of human rights infractions, leading to guilty verdicts.
dialogs.answer: As these files were at risk of destruction by political enemies or through neglect, a copy was sent abroad, in line with the principle of Dealing with the Past (#1).

dialogs.text: In 1993, the Commission on the Truth for El Salvador completed its report on abuses committed during the Salvadorian Civil war and transferred its archives to the UN. However, the documentation did not include how long the UN could hold on to these files, nor who was authorized to ask for the files to be transferred back to El Salvador. The files remain with the UN and are closed.
dialogs.answer: Although the El Salvadorian government has requested for access, their claim to ownership and access has not been establisshed. An agreement outlining clear Ownership (#10) and Duration (#11) principles would have been helpful in this case.

dialogs.text: The Blinken Open Society Archives in Budapest holds archives containing sensitive data including those of the UN Expert Commission on Investigating War Crimes in the former Yugoslavia. Copies of the data have been created and deposited to another institution, after the political climate in Hungary became increasingly hostile.
dialogs.answer: This safe haven solution of copying and depositing elsewhere becomes necessary when the Physical Characteristics Principle (#16) is not met by the hosting country.

dialogs.text: During an emergency, an NGO in Africa handed a digital copy of sensitive records to an international human rights NGO in Europe, and both organizations had an oral agreement. When the sending institution attempted to claim the records years later, the person who they had the oral agreement with was no longer there. The hosting institution then claimed they owned these records.
dialogs.answer: Even in urgent situations, solutions should be guided by the Guiding Principles. At the very least principles #2, 5, 6, 7, 8 and 10 should be adhered to and the others implemented later.
